text:
Because nominal GDP is based on current prices, inflation will increase nominal GDP
even if the physical output of goods and services remains constant from one year to
the next. Real GDP measures the output of the economy using prices from a base year,
removing the effect of changes in prices so that inflation is not counted as economic
growth.
Real GDP is calculated relative to a base year. By using base-year prices and current-year
output quantities, real GDP growth reflects only increases in total output, not simply
increases (or decreases) in the money value of total output.
